I have always used other apps in the past for tracking activities but I primarily moved over to Strava for integrations like Charity Miles where I can track things but also do it for charity while still having visibility on stats for me. I think Strava is great at the basics and I have loved being able to do work outs with people and how easy it is to include others so you don‚Äôt both have to track the same route.

All that being said I have struggled with the interface both app and online in understanding how to see certain stats or PR times. From taking time I have found some of the things but it‚Äôs not as straight forward as other tools I have used. Maybe it‚Äôs behind the premium paywall but I do miss things from other apps but again the charity miles integration is keeping me here.
title: Pretty good app with great integrations

review: Latest update is really ill advised. For me what set Strava apart from the hundreds of other fitness trackers was the segment leaderboard and segment history features. With these core features now behind a very expensive paywall, I don‚Äôt see how they‚Äôll possibly attract new users (no one is going to just jump in and start paying the huge premium without understanding these features first hand).  And, as current users who are unwilling or unable to pay the large premium slowly move away from the app, the leaderboard concept loses much of it‚Äôs value.  What fun is competing over and over against the same 3 people in town who choose to be subscribers!? Seems like a death spiral in the making. Really weird and unfortunate ‚Äúupgrade‚Äù! I had been seriously considering signing up for the premium service, but this update struck me as really obnoxious, and also makes me question whether the leaderboards will even be worth paying for in a few months once everyone leaves.
title: Now just another fitness tracker...

review:
I would normally give Strava 4 or 5 stars: it‚Äôs a good app to track walking/hiking, runs, and cycling. The segment feature is actually interesting and useful to track performance along various parts of a route, and it may inspire some friendly competition or help set a goal. The interface is easy to use, though swapping  from the stats view to the map can happen accidentally.

But with the latest update, once you finish recording an activity, it immediately uploads it. The screen where you can title, add comments, and change who can view now has to be accessed by editing the activity. I don‚Äôt appreciate being required to hop through extra screens to title my activities and add comments. If there were a way to instruct Strava on how to title something, it would be a little more bearable. But lacking that feature, it‚Äôs quite irritating.
title: Update makes more work

review: Great app. I have been using it for years and I love the flyby feature. Please add Siri support so you can start recording a ride using Siri. For example, Siri integration would allow me to say ‚ÄúHey Siri, start recording with Strava‚Äù or something along the lines of that. This will allow users to start rides without fumbling with their phone and having to open the app. Very helpful if you are wearing biking gloves or if you are biking and cannot divert a lot of attention to the phone. My ski tracker app called ‚Äúsnoww‚Äù has this feature along with apps such as ‚ÄúLyft‚Äù which allow you to request rides using Siri. I contacted the support team about this and they responded with a canned response describing the voice feedback feature which gives you updates during your ride. This is not the feature I am requesting or talking about. That is a pathetic response.  Please add Siri integration. Thanks.
title: Siri

review:
Updated review. 

I have tried the subscription again and cancelled. There are just too many competing services that do what Strava does, but better. I still don‚Äôt like that features that were free continue to be put behind a paywall. And their training plans are a joke.  

Used to be the greatest addition to my workouts. More and more features are removed and the subscription service has been all over the place for the last few years. Final nail in the coffin for me is that they removed functionality to push data to apple health and my Apple Watch. Workouts no longer sync to my fitness app on my Apple Watch. Calories are no longer tracked. Strava also removed the ability to use cadence and other heart rate straps. I‚Äôve downgraded to a non-paying member since all of the features are included with garmin connect. I will most likely stop using Strava because of them discontinuing functionality with apple fitness.
title: Diminishing returns

review:
I have heard so much about Strava over the years, but was reluctant to add it bc I already track my runs so many ways - MapMyRun to share with friends, Nike+ Run Club for my lifetime running totals, achievements, and coached runs, and Garmin watch. I added Strava bc a virtual race I‚Äôm doing requires it and I thought I‚Äôd try it for a month of regular use with the free subscription. While I like the social aspects of this and the training data (still trying to learn what it all means!), there are several disappointing aspects that I can‚Äôt get past:
 - can‚Äôt use help/support feature in app (it repeatedly tells me to first confirm my email, I do, nothing changes)
 - can‚Äôt edit a run
 - can‚Äôt add shoes from the app, and can‚Äôt start shoes from the number of miles they already have
 - the training plan feature is absolutely bare bones. There is zero customization and no option for coached runs (fartlek, anyone?)
 - GPS tracking is wildly discrepant from my Garmin watch, which I‚Äôve used for years. Adds anywhere from .15-.2 mi extra distance on runs from 3-5mi in length. That‚Äôs a huge difference. It makes me look like I‚Äôm much faster than I am, but it gives me false PRs. Not cool, Strava. 

Bottom line for me: MMR and NRC do these things better and most of them for free. NRC is definitely the best value, even if Nike is constantly trying to sell me stuff.
title: Wish I could get into it

review: Strava: When users open a workout and are analyzing the speed, power, heart rate, cadence graphs for an indoor or stationary trainer workout, we need the cursor to show the specific workout time for any given moment in the workout. When I look at indoor trainer intervals, for example (I‚Äôm mainly a cyclist), I can see the simultaneous value for all the recorded metrics EXCEPT time. To be clear, I can see the simultaneous time readout for a geographic (outside) ride in the altitude graph just under the mileage. But when doing inside trainer workouts, those values, mileage and time, are lost. Of those, workout time (along with key recorded metrics) is most critical in analyzing an indoor trainer workout. Thank you for considering this addition!  Best, Tom Ehrhard, Strava Summit user.
title: Need cursor-based time readout for indoor training

review: Alright so I‚Äôm a runner in highschool and we use this app as a way to take countability for all of our runs and workouts, but lately it hasn‚Äôt been working too well. My school is doing a 100 day challenge throughout all sports and inorder for me to win this, I need to log in my stuff everyday, but I can‚Äôt. The app will freeze and kick me out for days, or I‚Äôll be on it mid recording and it‚Äôll log me out. I reinstalled it already once, and I‚Äôm now having to do it again. The reason was because I was on someone‚Äôs account giving a ‚ÄúKudos‚Äù and the app just did it. It just kicked me saying, ‚Äúyou‚Äôll need to reinstall due to your data not loading in.‚ÄùThis is a great app, but this definitely needs to change or become better in some way..
title: Kinda Big Kinda Small Issue

review: I‚Äôve used Strava for years and love it. Unfortunately the app is now failing to completely record activities. The first portion is recorded, usually either halfway or even a quarter of the way. When I finish the activity, I check the app and hit stop (I obviously never close the app while recording). Only when I finish do I see that the activity is incomplete. It‚Äôs not just a GPS issue, the time is hours off. This has been the case for hiking, biking, and running. And has failed in Texas, California, and Colorado in places with reception. Meanwhile, AllTrails always successfully records my routes. I am using an iPhone XS on iOS 15 and a mainstream carrier. I‚Äôm assuming there is a bug or an unintended increase in RAM usage that causes the OS to kill the app. I hope the dev team is able to address this in the next update!
title: Activities no longer fully recorded.

review:
I used premium for a month with a free trial and liked some of the features enough that I decided to subscribe. For some reason a week after getting charged all the premium features dropped off my app, despite it still saying I‚Äôm a premium subscriber. None of the suggested solutions on the support website worked, so I submitted a ticket. 

They got my hopes up by responding fairly quickly with a request for my payment receipt, but after sending that over I‚Äôve gotten no response for days. 

Aside from the robust community on Strava, the basic features are pretty much the same you‚Äôll get from any free app, so if you‚Äôre into the social aspect then basic Strava is probably a good pick for you. I‚Äôd be wary of giving them your money, however, as it looks like their customer support is notoriously bad, and there‚Äôs a chance you won‚Äôt even get the features you paid for.
title: Paid for features I‚Äôm not getting and support doesn‚Äôt respond

review: I have tried deleting and redownloading this app over 5 times today. It has not opened once. I see the giant orange screen with Strava pop up and then it crashes ever single time. If it wasn‚Äôt for the fact my colleagues I know uses it and we were hoping to compete I would have just moved on to another app. Absolute waste of my time. My phone is fine, my storage is fine I‚Äôve even reset my phone and tested other apps to make it was nothing else. And nope just Strava is crashing. Now not only will I have to use another app - my colleagues who are using will use that app with me so we can all compete together. I.e you just lost a lot of users. I‚Äôve been searching online for a fix and keep seeing others complaining of crashing. If you can help great I‚Äôll give it a try but if not please do something about this Apple or Strava. Oh and before you blame the ‚Äúuser‚Äù I work in tech and very familiar with troubleshooting, etc.
title: Beyond annoyed- just downloaded and only crashes

review:
Have been using Strava for over two years with iPhone app. No longer ‚Äúrun‚Äù...walk but use the run mode.  I really like the functionality of the program...I typically log 25 to 40 miles,13-15 minute miles in a Strava week...starts on Monday vice Sunday(European). Goals set, route and segments created, personal records documented...event, daily, weekly, monthly and yearly data all neatly organized...plus ‚Äúall time stats‚Äù...great tool... 
Equipment logged...for me, shoes tracked by miles...maintain list of when put in service and retired...8 pairs ‚Äúin stock‚Äù at the house...good for about 350 miles...  
Glad to pay the premium member subscription...albeit, I don‚Äôt use the functionality...just want to support and hope that we NEVER see ‚Äúadvertisements‚Äù...keep Strava ‚Äúpure‚Äù
title: I‚Äôm an old retired Fart on Medicare

review:
What with the last few updates to both this app and to iOS the application keeps on dying while I am using it. 

I would start my run and by the time I reached the half mile point I wouldn‚Äôt hear any indication and I would look at the iPhone screen and not see the little blue bar at the top of the display. I knew at that point that Strava  had stopped working and it would need to be restarted. This happened several times over the last few days and it is far too frustrating and annoying so I have moved on to other running apps. I had submitted a previous bug report which was to update my iPhone to the latest version of iOS (which I did) however that did not fully fix the problem.

By the wayI had already paid for a subscription.
title: I use to love this app

review:
You have to pick recording a run/cycle on either the watch app or the phone app. You can't view the map or stats on the phone while also recording heart rate data on the watch at the same time. Kind of lame.

Also, allowing data to be written to the Health app causes data overlap when recording with the phone, where the calories burned are added from the Strava app, but also added from the watch's "active energy" reading.

I've ended up using the Exercise app on the watch to record the workout to Apple Health with heart rate data, while using Strava with Health permissions disabled on the phone just to track the route. Which kind of makes purchasing Premium pointless
title: Doesn't work with watch and phone together

review: I‚Äôve been using strava for 3+ years now, and was a premium subscriber for 2 of those years. I used Strava to train for my first marathon run and the insights and stats linked with my watch were invaluable. However, life events happen and I cut back on some extra spending, including unsubscribing from Strava premium (it‚Äôs pretty expensive). Now, I‚Äôm realizing everything is locked behind a paywall. I can‚Äôt even see my best efforts now?? That‚Äôs a bit much. I get that certain features are premium tier (3D maps, effort levels), but things like best efforts and leaderboards should NOT be premium only. This is exploitation and although a lot of people will cave in the short term it will lead to a decrease in subscribers in the long run as people find other apps that don‚Äôt paywall basic features.
title: Locking everything behind a paywall ain‚Äôt cool..

review:
Overall good sports app, which however needs some major important functions added:

(i) There is no way to see your current pace on the Apple Watch 3 App when running. Only split (for 1km) and average for the whole workout can be seen. This is especially a problem when you do interval workouts like yasso800¬¥s, since you don‚Äôt know the speed for the 800m you are running. Other apps can easily do it and I don‚Äôt get the point why Strava just doesn¬¥t add a third option of current pace besides split and avg.

(ii) There is no way to use your Apple Watch 3 to record a swimming workout and upload it to Strava. The only thing you can do is upload a workout manually, but it won‚Äôt show you the splits not anything. The Apple Watch 3 is the most native device to iPhones and the activity app nicely records the swim data, so it there should either be an option to import that to Strava or do natively record a workout with the watch in Strava.

(iii) it would be nice if there were certain standard interval workouts added, so you can choose the pace you want to run and the distance for each split and the watch will tell you when to speed up/ slow down.

Hope to see some of these features added in the future! Keep up the good work!
title: Overall good sports app

review:
iPad: no app, unfortunate, could be used for the social networking planning aspect of fitness instead of having to constantly hold up a phone.

Apple Watch: don‚Äôt use the Apple Watch app. It‚Äôs a step backwards from the iOS/watch app built in. 1‚≠êÔ∏è iOS application does what it needs to do for connecting with other people using the application, to view social profiles, etc. although it‚Äôs quite painful to have to import Apple Watch-based activities. Also, given the outage I had the other day, those activities are at risk. 

 The Strava app on the Apple Watch is absolutely useless and doesn‚Äôt give as much data as the built-in application, so why use it? Why do I lose data about splits just because I‚Äôm using the strava app on my Apple Watch? If anything, a third-party app should give me more. Meanwhile, my workouts on my Mi band 6 seem to import automatically. So, quite weird.
title: Solid 2‚≠êÔ∏è app

review: I paid to have a subscription with Strava 10 years ago because I wanted them to be around for the cycling community and be successful.  I have to be honest, I‚Äôve been disappointed with their lack of consideration for the very people they originally intended to serve.  They erased all segments on Zwift, very disappointing.  They thought they were doing everyone a favor, they didn‚Äôt.  They erased or decided not to let you track your times or segments against other fellow club members.  They did away with annual best KOM / QOM‚Äôs.  I guess some riders either complained or had fragile egos, whatever.  Strava is downgrading to the point of ‚Äúmy ride‚Äù or other gps tracking apps.  It started out as a no nonsense app for competitive cyclists.  Now it seems as though they don‚Äôt want to hurt anyone‚Äôs feelings.  It‚Äôs too bad, they had a good thing.
title: Getting Dropped

review:
This is the Depository of all workout apps. If you use Garmin or Apple- it‚Äôs a must have.
You will see your friends workouts and be able to compare your workout to theirs...Seamlessly! 

Segments are so easy. Compare your times to other who have done the same route or a small portion of a route: Run or Bike. For example: I might have just bike 50 Miles. There might be 10 segments and I can choose any or all when I am done. Strava let‚Äôs me see how I did against: other males; females; how I ranked today- for the year- all time- and if you‚Äôre Premium then by weight and more!

Set up your own segment and watch how you rank. This is fun and motivating for me. Also- I love how it keeps track of my mileage YTD and I can see how many miles I road at a quick glance.

I love my Garmin Connect, but this lets me see my buddies and I can find and or follow all my friends and track how hard they work out by their HR score (Suffer Score?).

This is a must have app. Set your privacy setting to what your comfort level is if you just want to share with certain people.  

Learn, analyze and enjoy each workout with the App that gives back!
title: Great App! Fun and Serious ! Motivates!

review: I‚Äôve experienced the crashing problem only a few times in the recent update, but the most annoying problem is inaccurate tracking. I‚Äôll click start, it reads ‚Äúgps signal acquired‚Äù, and I‚Äôll start the run and when I check it after a few minutes it will be tracking the time but show no distance. When I stop the activity and go to the map, it always displays my location accurately, but it didn‚Äôt track what I‚Äôd done. The blue GPS icon on the top left of the screen still displays on the lock screen while I‚Äôm running, but it won‚Äôt record miles. It will be off an on for the duration of the run
title: Won‚Äôt track consistently

review:
I‚Äôm competitive, so this app is perfect. It has changed the way I work out. Fantastic.

Edit: lowered my review to three stars. Blatant cash grab from this most recent update. I‚Äôve loved this app for a long time but this is bad. All this right in the middle of a pandemic where money is short. It‚Äôs disappointing and I expected more. I understand that you devs need to eat, and I encourage you to try to make more money off of this great app BY IMPROVING PREMIUM FEATURES. I would actually buy premium (I promise) if you gave me even more analytics or an improved route maker or more goals options. Now I will NOT EVER buy premium to get back my favorite features because I‚Äôm principally opposed to being extorted. Give your loyal fans back the service we‚Äôve come to expect, and improve your paid service with new ideas.
title: Awesome but it got messed up

review:
It‚Äôs very disappointing how unreliable this app has become, in the beginning was good, now they only care about money and silly challenges. 

When I run open the app in both, Apple Watch and IPhone and always the distance is shorter on the Apple Watch between 0.1 to 0.6 miles, in top of that when I‚Äôm running I could see my moving time for mile on my phone but as soon as I finish only gives me the elapsed time which makes impossible to know the real pace. I exchanged a long chain of email with costumer service and the excuse was that ‚Äúengineers were working on the problem‚Äù, 2 months later and the same issue persists. Maps are lousy, especially in big city, it‚Äôs ridiculous that show me running on top of buildings or on the water. I just gave up and I won‚Äôt renew my subscription in June. Looking for alternatives, maybe Nike Run Club is better, or at least no as bad as this one.
title: Doesn‚Äôt work on iPhone

review: Strava‚Äôs Apple Watch integration remains terrible and they‚Äôve done nothing to improve it for more than a year. When you start an activity on the Strava app it loses heart rate data and you can‚Äôt see it on your watch. When you start an activity on your watch you lose out on audio queues and beacon and you can‚Äôt see it on your phone. So for cyclists with a phone mounted on their bike they are left with a terrible choice. A) no recorded heart rate data on the activity and feedback on their phone or B) heart rate data recorded but a black phone screen for the whole ride. No other running or biking app does it this way. It‚Äôs mind boggling that Strava is the only company in the space that doesn‚Äôt offer this functionality. Worse, there‚Äôs Strava forum posts with thousands of comments related to this issue and no reply from anyone at Strava. They‚Äôve completely abandoned their Apple Watch users. I‚Äôve cancelled my Strava premium plan over this issue.
title: Don‚Äôt use Strava with Apple Watch

review: The Strava app has many of the same features as Nike+ and RunKeeper but has the added bonus of accessing groups, expanded challenges, and viewing others runs.  Where it lacks is the ability to view (what in my opinion is most valuable) routes while running or biking. For those of us that like to try new routes, viewing them on the Apple Watch would be invaluable. For instance, on a new trail run yesterday I got lost twice and had to pull out my phone to backtrack since I cannot view the route on my watch. I think adding this feature would make Strava hands-down the best app for running, biking, hiking, etc.  This app is otherwise just average for those that would like to step away from their phone or computer.
title: Would be better if routes could be viewed on Apple Watch

review:
5/4/18 Update: What‚Äôs with the app asking which sport every time I start a ride? This appears to be a new feature and I hate it. It adds a whole unnecessary step to it all. I have bicycling as my default, so just take that and start recording! I don‚Äôt need extra steps between my starting the app and tracking my ride!!

Original Post:  So this is a great app and I use it for every ride I take. One feature that would be nice would be the ability to edit a segment of a ride, like delete part perhaps. I rode to a party and forgot to turn off the app when I got there so it tracked me walking around for 10 minutes before I realized. It'd be nice to delete out all of that walking around and have it reflect my true riding time and mileage. Otherwise, fantastic!!
title: Love this app! One suggestion...

review:
This app is the worst! I downloaded it to participate in a running contest with some friends. My loyalty to them is all that kept me from deleting the app the first time I used it. 

It is not at all intuitive, is less accurate than any other running app I‚Äôve used and the worst part is the Share setting. It is automatically enabled to the Everyone setting and there is no way to know that, until you inadvertently post your first run by saving it.

I‚Äôm coming back from an injury and am currently so slow I can‚Äôt keep up with my running group. Just getting out and moving again is a painful challenge and seeing my worst times posted for all the world to see made me want to give up rather than keep going.

 Fast or slow I‚Äôm not a person who likes to announce all of my activities to the world but this app only allows workouts to ‚Äúcount‚Äù toward challenges if they are posted for everyone to see. I couldn‚Äôt stomach it so I made most of my runs private and only posted enough to keep participating with my friends. I think the creators of this app should really reconsider if posting publicly should be a requirement to participate in challenges. Why does my effort only ‚Äúcount‚Äù if I brag about it? Shouldn‚Äôt it be enough for me to work privately to reach a personal goal? If my followers don‚Äôt see my run, did I even get off my couch?
title: Makes me appreciate Runkeeper so much more

review:
I‚Äôve been using Strava religiously for years and love it!  Thus, 4 stars.  As soon as they remedy the below item, I‚Äôll change this review and give them 5.
I don‚Äôt really get while they‚Äôve included manual activities like Kite surfing, Rock climbing, and Yoga - and with each update, they continually leave out any type of combat sport. As popular as the multitude of combat sports are these days, it seems like a conscious effort to exclude them.
And Yoga?  What possible metrics would you need to measure for yoga?
That said, my complaint is a minor and very specific complaint. So it‚Äôs not a big deal.  I still use Strava 5-7 x‚Äôs week for cycling, running, hiking, snowboarding, snowshoeing, and/or workouts.  And it‚Äôs been very reliable.
** premium user.
title: Have used Strava for many years.

review: I‚Äôve been using Strava app since 2012. It was an incredible simple program then but an awesome innovation to what motivates athletes (a race every day). At that time it was social but not intrusive. It allowed you to see other people if you knew there name by searching. Now it post people recommended by other friend‚Äôs connections, sort of the same algorithm as Facebook. It clutters the screen on the app. It is annoying to delete the suggestion just to have it show up again. If I wanted Facebook, I would use that instead   Some people may  request that feature but my friends agree it is annoying as well. The ability to add gear is not available on the app. I cannot figure out why.
title: Could be better

review:
I have heard it stated that Strava doesn‚Äôt know what it wants to be.  Is it a training platform app or a social media app?  I think it‚Äôs trying to be both and there are some drawbacks to not having a rooted identity.

In some ways the above is most likely at play when it comes to the virtue signaling going on with the company as well.  In June of 2023 Strava decided to promote a non-athletic cross dresser to promote their woke ideology.  This ‚Äúinfluencer‚Äù stated that they did not enjoy the sport of running or endurance but reluctantly promotes Strava.  Huh?!

I just cannot support companies that are this out of touch, relative to their customer base anymore.  Why not promote an athlete or an aspiring one?  All in the name of ‚Äúinclusion‚Äù but you are choosing to ignore, and in my case exclude, those that were on the app to socialize while training and had no need to shout their sexual identity from the rooftops.
title: App itself is the okay but had to cancel paid subscription due to woke agenda

review:
You want to track your mileage and get an idea of your speed and compare with friends? Awesome. This is for you!

Do you know what your FTP is? Your power zones? Your heart rate zones? Do you want to know how these evolve over time and see the impact that they make on your fitness? Yes? NOT FOR YOU. Strava has a major flaw in that any changes to your fitness measures will rewrite your entire history on the platform. So if your FTP goes up to 300 and you update it, Strava thinks you've always had 300 and will update all your old rides as if that were the case  this makes their Premium Fitness & Freshness feature completely useless. Strava even acknowledges this bug and seemingly has no interest at all in fixing it. What this tells me is that they aren't REALLY interested in being an excellent fitness app. They're interested in being a social app and accruing paying customers.
title: Great for casual but seriously lacking elsewhere

review:
I loved strava before they pulled the plug on having strava and garmin, for me, communicate together and send workout data to apple health. This allowed me to keep and review all my activities on my apple watch and it worked wonderfully. Then without warning they removed the communciation between the three. Well I hope they reconsider and put this feature back into play otherwise someone else will.
  UPDATE:  
 No one likes making mistakes but rectifying them when we do means a lot.  Thank you for reversing the apple Health communication  fiasco‚Ä¶I hope you find a better way of preventing duplicate workout sessions for some soon.
title: Strava doesn‚Äôt care about what user want. Nevermind‚Ä¶they do.

review:
I like the app to keep track of the miles I ride.  I would suggest one serious improvement, one wishful modification, and have had one user issue.

The serious improvement I‚Äôd like to see, is a more sensitive auto-pause mode.  I see many race-oriented cyclists running through stop signs.  I think Strava is contributing to this.  If the pause feature worked better, cyclists could stop at stop signs and be penalized less.

The issue I have is that my rides do not get saved frequently.  I have an iphone 8+ with the latest software update.  Sometimes I check my ride stats at the first stop, and there are none.  Sometimes I try to end and save a ride, and an older ride I did pops up instead.  Sometimes it looks like it‚Äôs saving a ride for me, but the upload simply fails.  This always happens when I get home, and have an excellent internet connection.

The wishful improvement I‚Äôd like to see is auto-record.  I used to use ‚ÄúMoves‚Äù before i started using Strava.  With that app, it records your rides the minute you leave the house.  You don‚Äôt have to launch the app and start it.  I often forget to start Strava, which results in me losing many miles.

Thanks!
title: Works Pretty Well

review:
I have been using Strava directly over the past few weeks because Wahoo Fitness developed a bug that caused it to constantly drain my battery even when completely closed and background permissions revoked. Strava retains the accuracy I was accustomed to with WF, and its auto-pausing and auto-resuming is far better. However, there are a few things I really miss from WF that I wish Strava had: prompts every 5 minutes with an audio summary of chosen stats; current speed display in addition to overall average; current BPM display in addition to overall average; sharing to other services (I like to export to RunKeeper for historical reasons). 

The lack of these features isn't enough to leave a 3 star review but they're enough to remove the fifth.
title: Pretty good. But missing some nice things

review:
After a year or so of hit-and-miss with the watch version's reliability, I had a solid year of excellent performance. Unfortunately, the latest updates have rendered the watch app unstable. I have uninstalled and reinstalled on multiple occasions - both on my phone and on my watch. More often than not, when I start a run on my watch, I get the Strava logo with a parade of dots running around in a circle until the app crashes. Sometimes it eventually loads but increasingly I just get frustrated and give up after 5 minutes.

I purchased my watch and Strava pro specifically for tracking and monitoring my runs. Unfortunately, Strava can't keep it's apps running in a stable fashion.
title: Apple Watch App Unstable

review:
Love everything about Strava and I‚Äôve been using it for years - biking and running. I don‚Äôt think anything else is even close.
Two things I would love to improve.
   One - precision. When people run, they rarely zigzag manically from one side to the other speeding up to an equine sprint, stopping and changing directions. It should be easy to figure out that a gps location keeps getting skewed by reflections from buildings or terrain and ignore those errant points, smooth out the path so it‚Äôs at least within the confines of the street. When this goes astray, the distance increases drastically and the speed gets miscalculated.
   Also, some places have bridges. Bridges and viaducts can go over lower terrain. It can‚Äôt be difficult to figure out that a runner is not traversing the surface of a river like a modern day Jesus Christ, but is going over a bridge and count elevation accordingly. If Jesus does come again and his walking across a body of water is incorrectly accounted for on Strava, he will forgive you. That‚Äôs kinda his thing. Short of that, why not figure out where bridges are and get the heights of their spans into the system.

Other than that, great work guys. Cheers.
title: Love the app, need better precision

review: Been using Strava for about 5 months. Previous running app was Endomondo sports tracker which recently retired by UA. I‚Äôm now training for my 6th marathon, and this is the first time training with another app. My favorite thing about Strava is how quickly the auto- pause feature responds. Now for the bad. I‚Äôve always cross checked the distance I run with google maps, knowing that no GPS is totally accurate. Strava‚Äôs distance tracking is a lot less accurate than my previous app. It‚Äôs always shorter than actual distance. And that can be very deceiving, especially for a newer runner that‚Äôs training. So I‚Äôd advise anyone not to put too much stock in the tracking data. That 10 mile run is more like a 9 miler etc.
title: Some good , some bad

review:
Strava has a great core product; I love being able to track all of my activities in a single place. Moreover, the open platform typically lets me use whatever sport-specific app I desire, but maintains a centralized view (with the exception of NRC/NTC, which I understand is more limitation on the Nike side).

I appreciate the continued work being put into the product. The new routes functionality is something I‚Äôve been looking for awhile. My hope is to see recommendations refreshed on some cadence, the feature is great now but loses legs if I see the same things over and over!

My one concern is in regards to data collection and privacy. In my opinion, you can tell a lot about a company based on their default settings, and Strava sets new profiles to ‚Äúopen‚Äù. For a new user who hasn‚Äôt discovered things such as privacy zones or flybys, they may be unknowingly sharing more info to the public than desired.

Additionally, while Strava does charge for 
some features, there is a lot of money to be made by selling data. This is not inherently bad; it could be sold to governments for urban planning, but could also be used to track individual‚Äôs routine movements.
title: Strava continues to impress

review: I‚Äôve used the Strava app for cycling a lot over the past couple years and have overall enjoyed it a lot. It‚Äôs easy to use and fun to check out all the stats and tracking and whatnot. The one thing I‚Äôve found very annoying from day one is that the app always has an in-app notification that ‚Äúyour ride has finished uploading‚Äù. I just feel like I don‚Äôt need that and sometimes it can drown out other, more important notifications like when people have commented or given me kudos on a ride. Maybe others like it but I‚Äôd at least like the option to turn those notifications off. They are completely unnecessary and useless to me.
title: Greatly enjoy the app but notifications are annoying

review: Like the app and the compatibility with my iWatch! Would love to have my iWatch have the capability with this app to have it ding/vibrate every mile so that I could be more aware of my turn to move to the front when group riding. That and maybe being able to pull up my average speed during a ride on my iWatch instead of having to wait till the end of the ride to see what my average was. These things are not deal breakers for me but I would love to see them as improvements. Love the app! It‚Äôs awesome for keeping track of my rides with my cycling buddies. Love the segment challenges to keep competing against others and push myself. Love getting badges on segments. I only have two apps that I use for cycling and my iWatch and Strava is my go to app for cycling. Thanks
title: My go to cycle app

review: I tried to use Strava so that I could follow a long bicycle route. It didn‚Äôt really function in the navigation capacity that I needed it to ‚Äî the map does not zoom in or out intelligently as you cruise on straightaways or approach complicated intersections, and it does not block the device screen from shutting off. The end result is that you need to constantly interact with your phone while riding which can lead to stressful and dangerous situations. Perhaps the most infuriating thing is that any tine I approach a hill the app goes into some ‚ÄúKOM‚Äù mode that hides the map, and the only way out is to end your ride within the app. I just want to ride my bike, not race. Please don‚Äôt do that. At least now I understand why so many hardcore-looking cyclists blast through stop signs and red lights ‚Äî they‚Äôre trying to ‚Äúwin‚Äù at Strava.
title: Not a great user experience during rides

review: They somehow can‚Äôt get the watch app to sync to the phone app so if you‚Äôre a bike rider you can either have a bike computer or you can have heart rate but not both.  Also, there‚Äôs a fun glitch with this review box where I can‚Äôt actually see what I‚Äôm typing so please excuse the errors.  I guess they don‚Äôt actually want people to review their app which h is understandable. The app works well for most cases, but if you‚Äôre a cyclist and you have an Apple Watch you want to use for heart rate while using the phone app for a cycling computer, no dice. One or the other bub. There‚Äôs a few threads in the support forums about this but they go back years with no vendor input so it looks like the devs aren‚Äôt going to add this feature back in. Also, if you‚Äôre interested in controlling your music from the app, you are again SOL. In other apps you can choose the playlist or artist to use during exercise and it would handle the rest but not this app!
title: Glaring flaw

review:
For swim analysis the fast split pace is slower than average pace, which is mathematically impossible.  Also the swim pace chart looks like 90% of the data is thrown away; the resulting chart looks marginally better than random, especially if you have a mix of intervals and long swim sets.  The stroke rate is called cadence, and I can‚Äôt tell if it counts ‚Äúone cycle‚Äù as both arms or one arm.  Pool length says 25 but not yards or meters, and I swim in both 25yd and 25m pools so the most important info is missing.
  The running pace chart shows an abnormally high amount of pace variation for a steady run (compared to my Garmin chart, and both are created from the same raw data.)
  At least the pace charts have meaningful labels on the axes.  Before the running pace chart would only label the 6:00/mi and 12:00/mi tick marks, but now it has every minute pace marked.
title: With latest release Strava stats and charts are still wrong

review: While i am using it since last 2 years with subscription but i recently tried to use it as my default running app on Apple Watch Series 8 and arghhh that was ugliest running experience i ever had with any watch app. Firstly it shows a time screensaver type and you have to lift wrist and wait to see ongoing progress. Then for most and especially middle age runners important things are heart beat and distance covered, which if you are in 40s are visually very small and very difficult to read. Also there are no audio or hepatic alerts for Heart Rate, Pace or Cadence. Customisation should be there for running data on watch app. That minus 1 star just for running inconvenient
title: Great record keeping but poor running app

review:
I previously used Fitbit charge4 to record my CrossFit workouts. it was awesome! When finished, use the Fitbit app to analyze the entire workout (no subscription). You could see your heart rate through the whole work out, calorie burn, loved it.

I have recently ‚Äúupgraded‚Äú to Apple Watch. Strava has a great app for Apple Watch. I use it to record my GPS workouts (walks, runs, bike rides) and it works great. The problem is when I use the Watch app to record CrossFit or any other work out, after I finish the Watch shows the full time of the work out, but it up uploads to the Strava app with no data. Shows me I just did a ‚Äú0m 0s‚Äù workout. Why does Strava do this? I may have to resort to fitbit or Apple fitness for these types of workouts. Sorry Strava :-(.
title: Non-gps workouts record as 0m0s with no data

review: I switched to Strava from SportsTracker because the Love to Ride bike challenge thingy synchronized with Strava, but not Sports Tracker. I want an app that tracks my speed for a multitude of activities, maps my routes, and guesses at calories burned, etc.  Both Strava and ST fit that bill. I don‚Äôt need or want the more advanced features. The big difference from an end user standpoint is that when I complete a ride or other activity, Strava spends a long time processing before I can see my ride in my log and review it. And it‚Äôs lost some rides. Sports Tracker didn‚Äôt seem to have these issues; when you finished and saved an activity, you could view it right away. Not sure why Strava needs so much post processing time. If it weren‚Äôt for the synchronization with Love to Ride, I‚Äôd ditch it and go back to SPorts Tracker.
title: Good app, but sometimes slow

review: I‚Äôm new to Strava. I chose this app because it allows me to track a variety of activities in one app. My primary activities are hiking and walking with a little bit of cycling. I didn‚Äôt mind accessing the website to input the info on my bike and my shoes, however, I am concerned that the app will not track the mileage that I put on my shoes because I‚Äôm not logging my activity as ‚Äúrunning‚Äù. This info is just as important to hikers as it is to runners. My profile only shows running and cycling activities so it looks like I have done 0 miles. It appears as though it does not aggregate the miles I put on in other activities. I think we should be able to customize our profiles to show the activities that we actively engage in and get stats for those activities, regardless of what they are.
title: Not all athletes are runners.

review: I really enjoy using the app especially once I eat get it started. The creator(s) of this application have the athlete‚Äôs mindset. Once I start Strava, it records your location, activity, duration, elevation changes etc. I do not have to check the application multiple times. The app gives you direct voice feedback while your in the midst of the activity. Probably the only feature I would add at this point would be a reminder of sun rise or sun set for those on long bike trails. In addition, maybe it could potentially have a connection to weather channel  if there is a unscheduled weather pattern changes I.e. severe thunder storms and lighting, etc.
title: Stop and Start

review: I love the competitive segments when riding your bike but I just hate the terrible penalties you get when coming up on a red light. You can lose 3 seconds coming to a stop then another 3 trying to get back up to speed, but the worst part is when you come to a stop, the Strava timer continues for another TEN seconds !!! Why penalize me for stopping at a red light ?? I already lost time coming to a stop !! I talked to tech support 2 yrs ago and he stated that‚Äôs the way the designers did it and they did it for a reason and it‚Äôs not changing. I think that it‚Äôs stupid and not at all thought out. I did a 45 mi ride, hit 42 lights and was MUCH faster in my Sportstracker app because your time stops or pauses the second you stop then continues the second you take off again .... and much more realistic.
title: Stop lights kill your performance

review:
Strava has two very important premium features: Beacon, which lets loved ones or crew follow your ride in real time for safety; and Heart Rate monitoring via Apple Watch. Unfortunately, do to very poor programming, you can‚Äôt use both at the same time. To track heart rate you have to start the ride from your Watch - but to use Beacon, you have to start the ride from your phone. Neither phone nor Watch communicate with each other in real time, so you can‚Äôt use both - just one or the other.

I really can‚Äôt comprehend how a major faux-pas like this happens, and worse, Strava has known about it for almost two years now and hasn‚Äôt lifted a finger to fix it. Given the poor state of the app, I recommend using Cyclemeter instead. Unlike Strava, it WILL track both your heart rate and live broadcast your location at the same time. You know, the absolutely basic things you‚Äôd expect a $7/month app to do.
title: Basic Features Broken

review: I‚Äôve been using Strava for a while now and it has been very easy and comprehensive to use. I can accurately see how I am improving and how my friends are doing all while I‚Äôm on my bike, running, or taking a break from the water. It has really boosted my performance since I can use the challenges feature to push myself a little further each time I go. I also am able to go do activity with friends and invite them on events, which makes it easy to do group runs and rides, which is especially important on events in places like roads or far from any city. Overall I would highly recommend this if you swim, bike, run, or do all three.
title: Love this app, perfect for triathletes!

review: Strava is overall, an excellent app. I run high school cross country and track, and through Strava, it has kept me motivated to train day-in and day-out. The fact that so many runners use the app, enables me to follow other excellent high school runners, as well as all-time great runners such as Jim Walmsley among others. It really allows you to analyze runners that spent their life finding the right balance between mileage and workouts, and by being able to access this, has given me a whole new prospective on training. KUDOS to the developers of Strava for creating such a motivational and inspiring app that I will continue to use for many, many years to come.
title: A Review from a Real Runner

review: I used to love strava but the most recent update has taken away the most basic and essential function of the app, tracking your weekly miles. Seriously?!? I get that they want to try to push the premium subscription but taking away this feature essentially forced everyone‚Äôs hand by making the app essentially useless without the subscription. With everything going on in the world right now Strava is just exploiting the situation and forcing everyone to pay for the most basic things and it‚Äôs not right. I am extremely disappointed by how aggressive they are becoming with their premium venture. If the subscription was cheaper I‚Äôd consider it but the way they are going about it is so frustrating that I‚Äôm just going to go somewhere else since it doesn‚Äôt seem to any other choice, there essentially is no free version now.
title: So disappointed

review: I love having a shareable log of all my activities, heart race and pace histories, lists of my personal records and automatic notifications when I break them. The achievement system gamifies my runs and the monthly fitness levels keep me self aware of my training on a longer term level. I also like how it automatically detects when I do the same route, and then gives me a history of my performance on that same route / activity / run / ride. I love Strava so much I applied to work there as a software engineer an eon ago, haven‚Äôt heard back though ü§£ it‚Äôs basically social networking for athletes, real athletes not wannabes
title: Long time user, recently went premium

review:
The app for the Apple Watch has many problems. (1) if you start a run and immediately want to stop it, you cannot. The app must detect significant motion motion which makes it not worth using. (2) I uninstalled the app and reinstalled it to deal with the previous issue. My watch told me that i need to login to my account on my phone for it to work, but when I went on my phone app I was logged in and it said my watch was set up. (3) it often does not account for parts of my runs and gets the time - and therefore pace - super inaccurate. For example, I will run 2.5 at about 7 min pace in reality and it will record that I actually ran 4 min avg pace and my first mile took a minute which which is obviously just wrong. 

I really would like to use this platform but the watch app is just so disfunctional that I would not recommend it and will switch myself if these problems are not dealt with soon.
title: Apple Watch app

review:
The new map updates are neat, but for navigating during rides and using the global heatmap performance is way worse. Most of the time during a ride or when planning rides I just want to be able to see the heatmap. Suggested routes are great, but using a bit of local knowledge combined with using the heatmap has given time the best routes in new areas. That‚Äôs no longer a good option, with the ‚Äúsegments‚Äù tab overlapping the heatmap and making it unusable, and performance in the ‚Äúroutes‚Äù tab being absysmal, even with an iPhone 12.

I‚Äôve found filtering for segments of length 0 miles makes the global and my personal heatmap somewhat usable, but it‚Äôs still worse than before the update. Just give me a heatmap only view please!
title: In app heat map unusable with new update

review: I manage a bicycle shop and have personally introduced and recommended Strava to 100‚Äôs of cyclists. There were many great features, with lots of detailed data and useful information. Unfortunately the most unique feature, which was being able to compete with your friends and foes for trophies and top times, etc... has recently been rendered mostly useless!! This is a huge disappointment and unfortunate recent change to the App :-(((( Now most of the segments are not even possible to find. There are other Apps that do a lot of the same things you get in Strava. Unless they bring back the segment explore features to their previous functionality it will continue to be a very disappointing app!!!!
title: Hero to Zero !

review: Nice app interface for basic functions. The social aspect isn‚Äôt too intrusive which is nice. It‚Äôs fun being able to compare times on different run segments. There‚Äôs some data in the pro version that isn‚Äôt accessible on the app which makes the pro version less desirable. Garmin uploads seamlessly which is nice. Some of the King of the Hill top times could be weeded out as there are impossible times (ie 1/4 mile run uphill has a king of the hill at <30 seconds). I understand why some of the pro features are paid (data analysis, Training plans, etc) but there are a few really basic features that are only for the pro version that should be accessible in the free version like setting a mileage goal for the week. Overall average app that I‚Äôd like to see improve because I use it all the time!
title: Decent

review: This app used to be great to track my runs and see my weekly mileage on my profile. A few days ago, I went to see how many more miles I had left this week and it said I had to upgrade to premium. I don‚Äôt think I should have to pay to see that. One other issue I have with this app is that when I view someone else‚Äôs profile, it shows a graph going further back with the past few months, but I can‚Äôt see it on my own profile so I just have someone else screenshot it and sent it to me. I am really frustrated because I don‚Äôt feel like I should have to pay to see my graph. Please change it thanks ‚ù§Ô∏è
title: One star!!

review: I‚Äôm not going to pay for any subscription when the features we use to access were free. It‚Äôs sad that the heads of the app decided to get greedy as opposed to sourcing adds and keeping it free. Common guys. I‚Äôm no one and I thought of that one all by myself. Keep the advice at no charge or..... it will be $60 every year for the use of the idea. Doesn‚Äôt seem right you say? Exactly what all of the old users of this app feel like. We made Strava what it is. With our hiking, walking, running, swimming, cycling, MTB etc. groups and the word of mouth that kept this app on the map. I‚Äôll be looking for a new app as this app also has trouble linking with Garmins, Apple Watch and other smart watches. I‚Äôve lost data on a bad sync and it‚Äôs not worth $60 to have an app this weak. Have a good day.
title: Charging for features that were free b4

review: Keep looking for a better app or use Apple Activity for a reliable and stable platform. Reported a problem 19 days ago and all I got was an email saying ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll respond as soon as possible.‚Äù  19 days. In those 19 days the app was never stable or consistent. It missed workouts that were recorded.  The Apple Watch app would either not open, sometimes disappear, or repeatedly reinstall itself. Hopes it would work on iPhone X and latest Apple Watch. How totally disappointed I was. I tried this app because of a Trek bike challenge. I‚Äôve told Trek they can find better partners. If you want an app that crashes, does not preform properly, does not record workout correctly, and has a tech support that is not helpful or responsive, then this is the app for you.  I can‚Äôt imagine paying for their premium Summit service where you would actually be paying for a bad product and bad service.
title: Horrible app, horrible tech support

review: I‚Äôve been using Strava to log my runs and rides. I enjoy the accuracy and features this app provides. One thing that I miss from using the Nike Run app is that if you open it from the phone and your Apple Watch is connected, it will show you the data on your Apple Watch and use it as a heart rate monitor. For strava, if I start it up on my iPhone, it won‚Äôt show the live data on the Apple Watch or use the Apple Watch‚Äôs sensor. A little disappointed that it does not allow that. I have to constantly start the app from the Watch, but then that doesn‚Äôt allow me to send my beacon alerts. Would love for this feature to be added; having both units in sync, especially when initiated from the phone.
title: Active Sync with Apple Watch?

review: A friend of mine told me about Strava. Before, I used to run according to my emotions, but when I started to use Strava I was able to know how far and how fast I was running. This encouraged me to do more physical activities (not just running). Strava helped me realize my potential as an athlete. It also help me push myself in between my busy life and my lack of time because with Strava, you can keep a record of every movement you make. I can also follow friends and people that are great athletes, and this encouraged me, inspired me and helped me to keep persevering in a more active life that now I can have thanks to this great app: Strava!
title: Strava helped me improve

review:
We are currently doing a challenge using Strava to track the data. When we first started using it, in order to log a manual workout, you had to go to the website. This was fine, since it allowed me to track my incline trainer time AND elevation. 
   With the recent updates a couple things have happened. If you log in online, it forces you straight to the app. They HAVE updated it to allow you to create a manual entry, but the selection list is still limited, unlike on the website, (no option for stationary equipment), AND there is no way to capture elevation gains. 
   It would also be nice to be able to log elevation losses as well as gains. Going down an incline puts different stress on the hips and knees.
title: Forced to use the app

review: I have loved Strava for a long time but now they are doing away with Bluetooth connectivity in the app for heart rate monitors and power meters. They say it is because the app crashes, why not just fix the problem? Without the connection strava will require you to use a third party if you would like to upload your data, my question now is what is the point of strava if I need to use a third party app to get data? One of the major things strava peaks offers is data based on heart rate meaning it will measure the HR and assign a number value for how hard you worked on a given workout, but with out HR connection this is a useless feature. There certainly is no reason to pay for strava (I am canceling my strava peaks) and I can‚Äôt find a reason to use the free version when the third party app will provide me the data I need with the connectivity. Strava was great but now seams completely irrelevant.
title: No Bluetooth connection

review:
For the good part: it tracks your workout really well. It gives you useful stats. Great when riding in teams‚Ä¶
For the bad part: impossible to see your stats with a custom date range. I wanted to see how many miles I have ridden with my new bike but had to do the math by hand‚Ä¶ really? You have all the stats in the world but you couldn‚Äôt be bothered implementing such as simple function? I guess you get what they give you and you shut up. Why am I saying that? We‚Äôll because when reach Inc. out to support asking if such a function is possible, just in case I missed it somewhere‚Ä¶ no response. I have a paid subscription for the record.
Furthermore, the in app, support doesn‚Äôt work. I was kind enough to take the time to report it with a screen recording‚Ä¶ no response from support AGAIN!
title: Good and bad

review:
Tried Strava for the first time tonight and am less than impressed. I‚Äôm looking for an app that will a) track properly, b) freaking know when I start and stop, c) integrate/handoff with BOTH my Apple phone AND watch at the SAME time.
This app literally halfway accomplished a) and absolutely nothing else. It started two independent workouts, one on my phone and one on my watch. In spite of my having the settings for auto start/stop, it just kept on ticking by until I either rolled my sleeve back off my watch and/or dug around in my pocket for my phone, then squinted my eyes and scrolled around on each device to pause and start back. 
However, the app was VERY pro-active in letting me know I could subscribe to your miserable service. Why would I subscribe service... pay actual money, for something that frustrates the crap out of me?
title: No better than RunKeeper

review:
I would give it 5 stars if the website was easier to understand when making segments public.  
I'm not a competitive rider.  More like stop and smell the roses mountain biker.   My friends on the other hand are hard core.  One of em' turned me on to Strava.  And all I want to do now is  beat my PR's and pour over the data to see how I did and where to improve.  Also compare to other riders.   I'm not fast enough to get any KOM's.  Unless it's a segment I just made or rarely ridden segment with slackers that week.  üòú.   Oh and the Evil part goes out to all those that don't want their private trails revealed.  I've been trespassing on most of my rides for ever and I didn't need Strava for that!!!   Happy trails!!
title: ‚ù§Ô∏è Evil Strava

review: I‚Äôve been using strava on my mobile for months with relatively little issues. I recently purchased an Apple Watch to be able to go on runs without lugging around a clunky phone. The first few runs went well, and I was able to sync my forms from my Apple Watch to my iPhone without any issues. However, my last two runs did not work well. The first one refuses to sync with my phone. I tried all the tips online to no avail. It still won‚Äôt sync. I tried another run this morning and this time when I finished my run and went to save, the run would not save. No matter how many times I pressed ‚Äúsave‚Äù nothing would happen. I exited the app and came back and my run was gone. It‚Äôs unfortunate because I really did like the mobile app. But losing two runs is a bit frustrating and I will not be risking that again, so I will have to find another running app.
title: Apple Watch App Problems

review:
Strava couldn‚Äôt figure out how to reliably incorporate Bluetooth devices into the app, such as heart rate, watt meters, etc. so they just completely pulled support from under existing users. Despite an abundance of other apps being able to do this reliably, and Strava charging a premium price for their product Strava can‚Äôt seem to get their act together. I honestly can‚Äôt fathom why Strava can‚Äôt fix this, but as a SW Engineer working in BT myself I have to say this is on Strava. For many of us this is a complete failure on their part and the reason they are losing ~$80 per year from me moving forward.
Strava claims to be a pro level cycling app but this issue and other glitches in their software along with poor support of their users indicate the opposite.
title: No support for Bluetooth

review:
I want to love this app and I do like the community aspect of Strava, however the UI while running had gotten me so frustrated I'm staying to look around. 

I don't own a smartwatch so my interface is the phone in an armband strap. That means I'm pushing the touchscreen through a plastic shield admittedly less than ideal. 

Couple of things:
1. I keep accidentally going into the map mode while I'm running. I don't need map mode I know where I'm going. It took me forever to understand how to get back to the big numbers that show your pace etc. That's really hard to find. 
2. Auto pause works like crap. It autopauses when I'm walking up a steep hill or does not pause when I'm taking a break and actually stopped.

I think the running mode should only have giant buttons. Having a little "hide" button on the top right of your screen when you are running and trying to manipulate the app through an armband is useless. The all could also use better smarts around track record. Like when it auto-pauses when I am still running and then didn't figure that out post factum to backfill the data. 

Anyway I have lots more, but just know this app feels like a cycling app that was also turned into a running app
title: Poor user interface while running

review: I was having a very good experience with Strava, and I understand the need to go more toward a full subscription service to strengthen the company. What I am not happy with is the fact that now, because my Strava and my NRC both took data from my Garmin watch, and were linked, I woke up today and my NRC is now locked and tells me I must ‚Äúpurchase‚Äù it in the App store. The only problem is that NRC is a free App. So now, whether I decide to upgrade to a paid Strava account or not, my NRC is being held hostage. I don‚Äôt believe that Strava should have released the new mandatory pay version without working out the basic interface issues that might occur. At the very least, the new program should not interfere with the function ANY third party program, especially when one is now a mandatory pay service and the other is still free.
title: Strava Locked my Nike Run Club App

review: There was this one hill segment that I liked to go up every ride and try to get into top 3 best times. There was also a steep downhill segment- which I didn‚Äôt do. Both of these segments existed several days ago, before those people who think that segments on steep hills kill people. They think that people want to get KOMs and go downhill at 40+ mph = kill themselves. I would understand if only downhill segments would be deleted = but the people who manage this area also deleted the UPHILL segments, which doesn‚Äôt actually hurt anyone and instead makes people try to become better to beat their PR. Please, return the UPHILL segments. I beg.
title: About segments

review:
Strava is good in a lot of ways, but coming from Runkeeper it‚Äôs absolutely baffling that Strava doesn‚Äôt support custom run splits. By that I mean being able to set my own distance OR time that defines a split. How is this not a minimum viable feature for a running app?

Want to do sprint/walk intervals every minute? Can‚Äôt do it in Strava since audio and push notifications only support a split every half or mile.

What if you want to do quarter or even 1/10 mile splits? Nope, can‚Äôt do that either.

This is crazy and maybe I‚Äôm just plain ignorant but the level of effort to add such a feature of being able to toggle time and/or distance AND customize that value seems so, so low. Like, there is already a selector in the UI under options. How hard could it be to open that up to 1/10, 1/4 of a mile in addition to adding a time selector? Like a week of a single developer‚Äôs work?

I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm not the first user to ask for either.

Please: Strava is really good in a lot of ways and you certainly have the market captured but HIT runners want this feature.
title: Good App, but Missing Custom Splits

review:
Hands down the best app for cycling and running.  Still hoping for more privacy control and local moderation of segment creation. 

To all the whiners out there too cheap to fork a few dollars a month....  we‚Äôve had nine years of free Strava with no ads.  Incentive to pay were too low.  I only went premium years ago to support them, not for the features. Now it actually makes sense to subscribe.  This is much better than going the ad route, and makes me hope they become profitable. 

There are free options for those who don‚Äôt like the cost. It‚Äôs easy to download all you tracks to move on.  So why so much complaining?  Developers need to eat, too.  The freeloaders‚Äô entitlement is pathetic.
title: Very good. You get what you pay for!

review: I don‚Äôt know whether it‚Äôs Strava, iOS12 Health app or WatchOS5 Activity app but calories from Strava workouts are not flowing to either Health or Activity. The workouts appear on Health and Activity but not the calories.  I‚Äôve done all the typical fixes including reinstalling Strava but the problem persists for both my wife and I. Hopefully either Strava or Apple or both will address this.  Funny how I‚Äôm just adding to my earlier review. As of this morning, the Strava workouts now appear on my watch but not the calories or the amount of time the workout took. It‚Äôs nice that workouts from the Apple Activity App come to Strava but it‚Äôd be nice if all my Strava data would make it to the Apple Watch. This smacks of poor programming/coding as well as inadequate quality control. Maybe you need new programmers/coders?
title: Still a problem

review:
This is my second season using Strava for road cycling. This year, it sometimes ‚Äúlooses me‚Äù near the end of a ride and then when I finish, it just draws a line from where it lost me to where I stopped.

I use a C-dale cycle computer that I‚Äôve calibrated to exact distances. Strava under and over reports the distances of my rides, sometimes by as much as 0.5 miles per 12 mile rides. Also, Strava consistently over reports max speed. Cycle computer reported 30.1, 30.3, and 29.1 and Strava‚Äôs numbers were 48.1, 45.0, and 36.9 for the same rides. 

But the worst is calories burned. I used four different methods to track calories (HRM, cycle computer, fitness tracker set to cycling, and calculated from ride data).  Those four vary slightly from ride to ride but generally give similar numbers for calories burned. But the Strava numbers are always about half of those other four methods (with a low of 41% lower and a high of 60.5% lower).  I contacted Strava and provided complete details. Their response was basically ‚Äúwe like our method‚Äù. 

The only reason I keep using it is because it tracks my efforts on various segments of rides and lets me know when I‚Äôve improved on segments. I just wish the rest of the app was more accurate.
title: Needs Improvement

review:
Strava brought biking to a whole new level. 5 stars. But what happened to the stared segments? Since a few updates the stared segments disappeared, its the biggest bug in smartphone history, please bring back the stared segments.
Now its showing a few random not interesting segments, I have to click all segments and when im there its hard to find the interesting segments because the stars are gone.

I first started to track my rides to know how far I go in a day, why dont Strava show total distance for the day? I used to get around that problem with connecting to health, and I could see total distance of the day in health, but that function stopped working.
title: Stared segments

review: I have been loving strava. However, the suggested routes for running are not ideal routes AT ALL. They take you on mostly main roads with no shoulders or sidewalks. I haven‚Äôt been able to use this function at all because of this issue. I know these aren‚Äôt user data sourced either, because I never see people running on these roads-because they are dangerous! Strava, use the data you already have of where people run to make legitimate suggestions. It‚Äôs also not hard to pull data from Google about traffic patterns. There‚Äôs no reason this can‚Äôt be a good feature. I‚Äôve used feedback suggestions many months ago for all of these dangerous suggested routes, and nothing has changed.
title: Dangerous Suggested Routes

review:
Too fast on running too slow on swimming....

For running, Strava computes its own moving time if you stop during a race at a water station Strava will not account for it even though you did not stop your watch. You have therefore a better racing time than the official time ( Kilian Jornet has a better time on Strava 18h46min than its official time at UTMB 19h16min). this is not accurate and was reported for years to Strava without any action ( check google). We lose accuracy shame. 
For indoor swimming I have the opposite problem, Strava is taking into account the time elapsed between the start and the end of the workout not considering the pause made with my spartan watch. This seems to be a new issue since Suunto has releases its new application Suunto replacing Movescount... accordingly my pace is too slow. 
Too fast on running too slow on swimming too much unaccuracy.
title: Inaccurate for pace and moving time

review: This app works just as well as other GPS apps, but there‚Äôs still much to be desired. First, it only reports distance to the tenth of a mile instead of hundredth. Second, it does not give you the option of choosing to hearing your average pace after every mile, but instead only tells you the total time and the time of the previous mile. Third, every time I start a run it will start, pause, then restart. Finally, you can‚Äôt preset how far you want to run, so if you‚Äôre running an out an back for an odd number of miles you need to stare at your phone/watch until it says 2.5 (if you‚Äôre running 5 miles for example). This issue is exacerbated by the first problem I mentioned. If my training program wasn‚Äôt linked to Strava I certainly wouldn‚Äôt be using it.
title: Meh

review:
There are two things that I cannot believe are still issues with the app.

1) When I try to search for routes and navigate to a place on a map, the routes don‚Äôt update and adjust. Then if you try to trigger the map to update, by adjusting the mileage or something, the map zooms back to your current location and not the location you‚Äôre looking at. Why do routes not update properly? Other location based apps do this so much better. 

2) The map easily disorients itself and tapping on the compass rarely seems to work. I don‚Äôt know if this is a Mapbox or Strava issue, but whoever‚Äôs it is, it makes the app perform super poorly when you‚Äôre tired and trying to navigate a run or ride.
title: App is frustrating

review:
Strava has replaced all my other social services and apps completely, and so much more. So many great things in this app, for instance, PR tracking and notifications, Strava flybys, integration with endless other services and hardware, auto upload workouts from other devices, so many things it‚Äôs too long and vast to list all the features but those are some of my favorites but barely scratch the surface.

If you are interested in working out, and interested in sharing the activity with your friends and tracking it like a video game: this is for you, very good for workout motivation also.
title: The best app

review:
My old tracker app was not going to be supported by iOS 11 and a friend recommended Strava. I really like the app and appreciate that it does everything I need despite the focus on social networking which isn't my cup of tea.

The one thing that really bugs me is Strava's requirement for Background App Refresh to be active. I never needed to have that on for my previous tracker and I don't even need it for most apps which handle GPS and data functions just like Strava. I usually leave that function off to preserve battery life so it is an extra step (along with turning on location services) I have to take when starting Strava. If it could be updated to eliminate that requirement, I would give this app 4.5 stars (I know I have to pick an integer).
title: Why Background App Refresh?

review: I am a Strava junkie. I joined 4 years ago out of desperation to see what my husband was doing online for an hour after he came in from a long weekend ride. What I found was a global cycling community that does fascinating rides and posts terrific photos. I follow Tour de France pros and British housewives who create art with their routes and my local club buddies. I pit myself against climbing hotshots and mega-milers, happy to just be somewhere on a list with them. I upgraded to a Garmin 530 and I use a Garmin heart rate monitor. I sync with my iPhone and other than the occasional glitch overseas, I have had no trouble. And my marriage is better than ever!
title: Social Media for Cyclists

review: I love your app and recommend it, but please I‚Äôm begging for the double-digit when calculating distance (we need to the one-hundredth), for example 2.9 is not as informative as 2.99!  I really would like to use just your app instead of yours plus a second app which gives me that detail. We need this feature on the Apple Watch version!!  I LOVE the fact that Strava remembers my segments and compares those runs - thank you!  Last wish would be to be able to touch a segment after the run (in the phone or web version) and see my pace or speed at that moment of the run, or that segment.  Thank you for the other amazing features!!
title: Need Double Digit

review:
I‚Äôve used Strava for four years to track biking and walking miles and I‚Äôve been generally thrilled. It‚Äôs accurate (checked against odometer and Google Earth) and convenient and does everything I really need. But the link to the Health app needs fixing. When I edit an event (add a description, fix a typo leaving the data strictly alone)  Strava adds a new record to Health rather than updating the existing record. So the particular event is duplicated and my total mileage, calorie and other data appears to double as tabulated in Health.
This should be an easy fix‚Äîjust delete the old record before adding the revised record.
title: Logging Data to Health app

review:
I have use this app now for at least five years was a paid member for year but I was stopped payment because of the ongoing difficulty recalling my walks my bike rides and taking pictures.
The Apple store stop recording when I take a picture and not pick it up I get a straight line from one picture to the next so therefore never called recording the proper distance please give me a hand on this one I would love to come subscribe again but not until this issue is fixed.
Please respond via email so I can respond back to you thank you
title: Can somebody help me with pictures and recording

review: I like the organization of the app, the interaction with friends, and how Strava shows your progress on routes you run often. I do not like how the pace that is posted is different than my actual pace, even with the auto pause turned off. If I have to stop because there is a red light on my route, I want that to stay calculated in my overall pace. I don‚Äôt want to think I run an 8 minute mile if I‚Äôm only running a 9 minute mile.  I‚Äôm also extremely annoyed with the GPS on this app. There have been multiple occasions where I run a quarter mile or more and strava just doesn‚Äôt pick it up. I don‚Äôt want to be cheated of mileage or need to stop during a run to restart my phone and app so that the rest of my run and pace isn‚Äôt effected by strava. I‚Äôve heard great things about run keeper and will be switching over.
title: Needs a lot of work

review: I have a had Strava for the last 5ish years and have loved it. I‚Äôve been paying for premium for a couple years now and couldn‚Äôt be more satisfied, but in the last two years I have tried to add a new email on file because I no longer have access to the one that is on file. I wanted to do this to make sure I don‚Äôt get locked out of my account but I also don‚Äôt remember my password. I have been trying to reach out to Strava for help but I have never heard back from them. I‚Äôve submitted several requests through their app and done what they ask but never reach out. I am giving them a poor review because you would think that they would want to help their customers especially one paying for it. They need to improve the app so I can do this on my own and create better customer service.
title: Never received help

review:
The functionality of both the iPhone & Apple Watch app work well. There is sometimes a lag between syncing if you don‚Äôt take your phone with you on a run & have to manually sync. But other than that everything works ok.

The low rating is specifically for the Strava Apple Watch app. 

It needs to be updated to take advantage of all the things that the watch is capable of which isn‚Äôt a lot but Watch OS5 does have some evolutionarily advancements that Strava ought to take advantage of.

As it stands, the Strava watch app is very basic. For example, there should be an option for interval training or perhaps  It wouldn‚Äôt be too difficult to add that functionality to the outdoor run section. Or how about the ability to gauge cadence with Watch OS5? These are very basic quality of life improvements that Strava engineers could easily patch into a future fix...but it‚Äôs been years with this outdated, behind the curve basic watch app which is a shame because most runners I know use Strava to track their workouts exclusively.
title: Apple Watch App Is Bad

review:
I have used and enjoyed other activity tracking apps. I, like many others, was introduced to Strava by a friend. I enjoy the social aspects, being encouraged by friends and in turn encouraging them. I enjoy having challenges to work toward. I love seeing how my runs compare to previous runs. I am glad that the developers keep trying to make the app better.

I tried premium but my training style is more casual so there was not as much value in it for me. A tiered subscription might be enticing for users who are not trying to be professional athletes. Plus my friends can already track me with other apps.
title: I main Strava these days

review:
I don‚Äôt really understand ‚Äî open water swimming is supported in the app but is essentially hidden within the features. The app is even called ‚ÄúStrava: Run, Ride, SWIM.‚Äù If you try to search for anything swimming related, Strava acts like they‚Äôve never heard it. You have to find a known local swimmer, then find a known workout, to find any hint of routes or segments for swimming.
